Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Situation2: An irate long-time customer challenges the legitimacy of the offer and demands thorough explanations.
Story: My phone buzzed with a new call just as I heard my stepbrother’s muffled sobs from the next room. He’d just found out his best friend was moving away, and I knew he needed me—he always did when things got rough. But I was on shift, headset already in place, and my supervisor had just reminded us about our call quotas. The line connected, and a customer’s angry voice filled my ear, demanding to know why our offer was “too good to be true.” I tried to focus, reciting the script, but my mind kept drifting to my brother, alone and hurting. I could hear him pacing, his distress almost tangible through the thin wall. My job demanded patience and professionalism, but my heart ached to drop everything and be there for him. The customer’s questions grew sharper, my brother’s sobs louder, and I felt myself pulled in two directions—torn between being the supportive sibling he needed and the reliable employee my boss expected. My hands shook as I weighed which role I could afford to let down.
